column9: Sanjay Gandhi National Park in Borivali East, Mumbai

column1: This is one of the most famous national parks in the country and is the most visited national park in the country. Sanjay Gandhi National Park was previously known as  Borivali National Park and was established in 1969. The park initially covered a smaller area of 20.26 square km until 1969, when it was increased to 104 square km by acquiring various forest reserves which were adjoining the park. The region is hilly with elevations between 30 m (98 ft) and 480 m (1,570 ft).
This is a  large protected area and is located at Borivali. Apart from a good forest cover, the park consists of two lakes, Vihar Lake and Tulsi Lake, which meet part of Mumbai's water requirements.
The park is considered to be the lungs of the city as it purifies much of the air pollution of this traffic congested city.
Flora and Fauna of Sanjay Gandhi National Park, Mumbai

The Borivali National Park houses a number of endangered species of flora and fauna. The forest area of the Park consists of over 1000 plant species, 251 species of migratory, land and water birds, 50,000 species of insects, 40 species of mammals. It is also home to 38 species of reptiles, 9 species of amphibians and also 150 species of butterflies and a large variety of fish.

The plants and trees that are found here are the Kadamba, teak, karanj, shisam, and species of acacia, ziziphus, euphorbia, flame of the forest and red silk cotton. There are a variety of flowering plants like Karvi or Karvy, a flowering plant that blooms just once in seven years.

The forest is home to many wild animals like Chital (or spotted deer), Rhesus Macaque and Bonnet Macaque. The various large animals that can be found here in the park are: Black Naped or Indian Hare, Muntjac (Barking Deer), Porcupine, Chevrotain (Mouse Deer), Hanuman, Asian Palm Civet or Gray Langur, Indian Flying-fox, Sambar Deer and Leopard. You can also spot hyena or four-horned.  Antelope. The Reptiles that live here include crocodiles in the Tulsi Lake, pythons, cobras, monitor lizards, Russell's Vipers, Bamboo Pit Viper and Ceylonese Cat Snakes.

There are a total of 172 species of butterflies that have been spotted at the Sanjay Gandhi National Park  Borivali, of which the noteworthy ones are the Blue Mormon, the Blue Oak leaf, the bright jezebels and Large Yellow and White Orange tips, Tigers, Eggflies and Sailers.

Some of the birds that can be spotted at the Borivali National Park are the Jungle Owlets, magpies, golden orioles, racket-tailed drongos, robins, hornbills, bulbuls,  minivets,  sunbirds, peacock, and woodpeckers. Migratory and local birds such as paradise flycatcher and different species of kingfishers, mynas,  swifts, gulls, egrets, drongos and herons have also been spotted.
